awd_titl_txt: REPEATED EVOLUTION IN BLACK AND WHITE: DETERMINANTS OF CONVERGENCE IN WHITE SANDS LIZARDS
awd_abstract_narration:
In this time of rapid environmental change, it is more important than ever to understand how living things respond to shifting conditions. How quickly can species adapt to environmental change? Do different species respond to new conditions in similar ways? A powerful way to answer these questions is to look to the recent past. This project uses a striking example of rapid adaptation - where several species have adapted to the same environmental change - to study the predictability of evolution. The backdrop for the project is White Sands, a dramatic gypsum dune field in New Mexico. The dunes are geologically young, and the stark white sands contrast dramatically with the brown soil of the surrounding desert. Over the last few thousand years, a number of animal species have evolved blanched coloration to camouflage with the white habitat. This project focuses on comparing patterns of evolution in three desert lizard species, all of which have rapidly adapted to the extreme White Sands environment. By studying the genomes of the white sands lizards and their neighboring dark soil relatives - the researchers can understand how quickly - and how predictably - adaptation occurs in novel environments. White Sands provides an example of "evolution in action" - a case of evolutionary change over short, observable timescales. It also provides a setting for education and outreach. The researchers teach an annual "Lizard Camp" for local low-income middle school students and an annual "Biodiversity Day" for public school Kindergarteners, and work with a variety of schools, parks, and publishers to provide educational materials that instill a sense of wonder about biological diversity and the scientific process. This project contributes to understanding rules of how, and how predictably, genetic changes lead to changes in organismal traits that are important for the survival of species in natural and managed environments.

It is often difficult to disentangle the contribution of different factors to adaptation in natural systems. However, White Sands offers replicated adaptation across multiple independent species, providing an opportunity to understand evolutionary predictability. The project applies an integrative genes-to-ecology approach to study the factors that determine the direction and magnitude of evolution in White Sands lizards. The project has three areas of investigation, focused on factors that influence whether species will exhibit a shared evolutionary response to changing conditions: natural selection, genomic architecture, and population demography. Mark-recapture studies will be used to quantify the strength of natural selection across species. Whole genome sequencing will be used to determine whether the genetic architecture of adaptive traits is parallel across species. Demographic modeling will be used to understand how gene flow affects phenotypic response across species. The approach explicitly integrates studies across multiple scales and methods in a single framework. Ultimately the research aims to reveal the factors that contribute to predictability of evolutionary change in the natural world.

por.por_cntn:
The biological diversity of planet Earth is astounding. Species have developed over millions of years in complex ecological networks. Yet sometimes, radical changes in the environment happen very quickly and disrupt these relationships. When environmental change is rapid, it often tests the limits of species ability to survive - and evolve – in new conditions. Human activities on our planet have precipitated a global biodiversity crisis, an extinction spasm that threatens to alter the composition of life on Earth. As we – as humans – figure out new ways of reconciling our relationship to the planet, we – as scientist – study how living things respond to rapid change.

 

Many of our best case-studies on rapid evolution focus on how species respond to non-anthropogenic change. These examples give us a window into how quickly species can evolve and what mechanisms underly this evolution. I have been fortunate to study one such example for the last 20 years. White Sands National Park is an iconic landscape feature in the southwest desert US. Its white gypsum dune contrast starkly with the surrounding dark adobe soils of the Chihuahuan Desert. The dunes are geologically recent, allow us an opportunity to study evolution-in-action. Many of the animals inhabiting White Sands have evolved blanched coloration to better camouflage and survive in this novel habitat. Therefore, we can study not only how quickly evolution can occur, but also how predictable evolutionary responses are across species.

 

The project applied an integrative approach – from studying individual molecules to entire ecosystems - to understand the evolution of the iconic White Sands lizards. We studied three primary factors that influence evolutionary predictability. First, we studied the dynamics of natural selection using a field “mark-recapture” approach where we measured the strength of selection in species natural habitat. Second, we studied the genetic basis of adaptation using whole genome sequencing to determine whether the same genetic pathways led to evolution in different species. Third, we studied population history using genetics and mathematical modeling to understand how the colonization of a new habitat could lead to predictable changes when animals are confronted with rapidly changing environments.

 

The research led to many different scientific products. We published papers in scientific journals, made presentations at national and international conferences, and published the first ever Global Change Biology textbook. In addition, this project had a strong outreach component. We offered a "Biodiversity Day" day where public school student visited UC Berkeley and a "Lizard Camp” where public school students visited field sites at White Sands. We also offered a large number of workshops at conferences and universities to help early-career scientists engage with questions about how to better align our science with what is needed at this moment of human history. Our integration of research, teaching, and outreach was designed to instill a sense of wonder about biodiversity and a sense of empowerment about the future of our species – and all species – on this planet.

 

If you’d like to learn more about the White Sands lizards, here is a short video sponsored by National Geographic: https://youtu.be/ACuj-pZBqug?feature=shared.
